title: The Data Economy: an opportunity for Greece

author: Nancy Routzouni, Ministry of Administrative Reform and e-Governance, Hellenic Republic

segmentation: It's a great pleasure to be a part of this so inspiring event here.

I would like to thank you for giving me the chance to discuss our policy and actions on open public sector data on creating value social and economic through the sharing of Greek public sector information.
To start this discussion, let's see how our current policies and results are evaluated by experts in the society that monitor our action.
This is the PS high scoreboard.

This is a crowd source tool to measure the status of open data use among the European countries, and actually it does not monitor government policies, but aims to assess their overall data reuse situation.
In this index, Greece scores 415 out of 700 and places 9th.
If we see closer.
The scoreboard measures 7 aspects of PS I reuse.
Although we are in a rather good position.
Compared to previous years, we see that we lack in formats.
We lack an exclusive arrangements we like and events and activities.
This is important information to consider in policymaking.
Another index is a open data barometer of the Web Index.
The web indexes designed produced by the World Wide Web Foundation.
The borrow meter explores how open data policy practice and impacts are developing around the world.
Greece places 37th in the 77 countries ranking, which is a low score considering that we place a lot higher 26th in the overall Web Index ranking.
It's also notable that we are 12 invariant freedom and openness in this same index.

This could be explained by the fact that although we recently have a number of strong transparency initiatives in grace, such as the transparency program, that the obvious that we heard earlier today.
The positive externalities of relevant open data implementations.
We think that are just now starting to spread.

In this index, but it is important to mention that Greece place is next to last among the OECD countries.
And next to last among the European Union countries.
This something important again.
In the recent years, the Ministry of Administrative, Reform and Electronic Governance has introduced the mechanism to reconnect citizens with the public administration.

A set of open government initiatives aim aiming to recover citizen confidence through the provision of reliable and quality services that promote growth, stimulate equal and active citizen participation, participation and improve their quality of life.
Our flagship Open Government Initiative is a transparency program, yeah?
Beginning October 1st, 2010, all government institutions are obliged to upload their acts and decisions on the Internet.
Of course, with special attention to issues of national security and sensitive personal data.
It's documented digitally signed.
And it is assigned a unique Internet uploading number.
We have 300 three 1600 public authorities entered the program.
And 11,000,000 million acts and decisions that have been published already.
The Deputy Minister Every Christopher Lapolla mentioned earlier today.
The ministries latest legislative initiative, according to which administrative acts and decisions are not valid.
Unless published on the on the transparent supporter.
The transparency program is considered an open government best practice.
And has been presented to many European and international conferences and other events receiving very positive feedback.
Implementation of this program is based on an agile strategy of open content and open data.
Allowing the dissemination and reuse of public sector information.
A major strength and innovation of Jabiim is it's open data service.
The service releases data in a dynamic way.
It makes it available on demand through an API that is provided.
DAV implements an ex ante approach.
Since its uploaded decision.
Are published a priore.
To their execution.
Thus forming a continuous stream of dynamic data to reuse.
Various applications have been built upon the open data access tools of javea.

One of the most notable is the public spending.net service, which is actually the first daily updated Web 3 application for public money based on the open data of Gabya, which are further validated by Greek tax data, the taxes system.
The most significant facts of public spending are visualized.
Connectit and compared to the most significant facts of foreign expenditure and other data resources in local and worldwide level.
This application contributes not only to communicate that you have yeah project, but also to provide important the ideas for the evolution of this project for us.
For example, a challenge for us now would be to follow public money all the way.
From budgets to actual spending.
An example.
Of how it is how this system tracks and analyzes the budget of the Municipality of Athens.
It's about 1 billion euro.
On a daily basis, both for simple and advanced users.
Another implementation based on the obvious open data service is hypergraphia.
I would translate this as something like meta transparency.
This is a search engine to provide full text search in public sector documents published by a variety of sources, sources that transparency portal.
Another source is the central website of National Printing House.
And also the eprocurement portal in Greece.
Notable features include real Time Search on Greek public sector documents.
OCR to extract all text information from this documents online.
Backup of documents in case government websites go offline.
But also modern design accessible through mobile devices.
This application has 1500 unique visitors.
And 6000 Page views every day.
And this is actually based on the open data of the avian and some and other sources.
Let's see some more smaller stories of public sector open data reuse.
We have their citizens on Duty application which is a web platform connecting citizens and information publishers based on geography.
This platform again accesses Java open date on a daily basis by using the API provided.
The data acquired are processed and enriched with other data sources and finally are presented to the citizens in the form of thematic Maps and pivot tables.
The cities are now have has ability to easily turn data into meaningful information.
Another example is the fuel prices application.
An application that uses fuel prices data shared by the Ministry of Development.
Using this application in the mobile phones, for example, users can find on a map the gas stations with the lowest fuel price near the position.
S Tim Berners Lee, the father of the World Wide Web, put it data online, will be used by other people to do wonderful things.
In ways that you can never imagine.
There is an increasing recognition of the open open public sector data initiative.
the G8 leaders released in June.
Their open data charter.
For scientists to open data and Open Access, offer new ways to research.
The European Commission launched in December 2011 the Open data package, so we have new EU laws.
To open up public administrations and we also have a new EU Open data portal.
To exploit this policy.
This morning we listen to the ministers and also the Vice President, Mrs Cruz and also other speakers discussing the strong potential of opening public sector data.
To produce value from making public administrations more transparent and stimulating, a rich, innovative market.
We believe that through opening and fully utilizing public information.
We can positively affect citizens lives.
This policy is also one of the Greek government commitments to the Open Government Partnership, which is an international platform of 60.
Three countries committed to make their governments more open, accountable and responsible to their citizens.
In October we had their annual summit.
Of ODP.
It was hosted in London and there we had 1500 participants from almost 100 countries.
In that cell mate there Deputy Minister, ever Christopher Palu, announced the government commitment to further unlock public sector information to actively endorse the principle of open by default.
To make all this happen.
We need to determine a solid policy.
For open data and apply this policy to all levels of the Greek public sector.
A policy aligned with the five core principles introduced by the G8 data Charter.
Open data by default.
Quality and quantity usable by all.
Releasing data for improved governance.
Releasing data for innovation.
Let's see our road map to get.
Is there?
First legislation.

We are currently undertaking annual legislative initiative on opening data, thereby adopting the principle of open by default for spacing cases of sensitive personal data, issues of national security, protection of IP rights, etc.
Government data will be promptly available online in open formats and common standards.
Thus, an ecosystem of open.
Interoperable services for sharing and reusing public sector information will be gradually established.

The proposed bill will also harmonize national legislation with the provisions of the PS I directive of 2013 on the use of public information long before the transposition deadline, which is for us June 2015.
The second we need to to manage the tools.
To implement our policy.
Up to now, the available public data sets were scattered on different public websites.
And in various formats that usually do not permit reuse.
Our goal is to create a new set of services and delivery models on open data through a central, centralized public repository.
Data go ger consolidate all sources of public information available.
On a single website, which is the focal point of concentration and distribution of public sector data?
Datasets are available with open licenses allowing further use according to our policy.
Datasets may derive from various thematic areas such as financial data.
Decisions of the state taxation and Social Security contributions environment construction.
Investment culture and tourism, which is very important for our country education and research.
Prices of products and services.
Efficiency of public services.
We have a long way to go in opening up all the senchal public sector data.
But we already, in the process of prioritizing or releasing at least of critical.
High value datasets.
To achieve our goal, we are in close cooperation with public sector administrative sector bodies to achieve their commitment to this policy.
In parallel, we have a very important and ongoing dialogue.
And deliberation process with the civil society because they know what they need from the public sector information.
Data Gov There provides also a mechanism for the citizens to pinpoint and vote for data sets that are of value to them.
But are not yet publicly available.
Citizens proposals are forwarded to the competent.
Public bodies and the relevant datasets are published with priority by them.
Our third mission is the culture.
In the coming.
The management of datasets on data Gov VR will be undertaken by public bodies.
The line ministries are responsible for ensuring the availability of data sets that fall under the jurisdiction given priority to those with high value.
That and that benefit the citizens and businesses.
We do not need that legislation ID platforms and codes.
Are very good but need to be matched with a culture that supports support.
Their presumption to release data.
I would like to mention some of the most demanding issues on this perspective.
1st.
Increasing interest and awareness of the public servants, the citizens and the private sector on the rights to access and reuse of public data.
2nd is recognizing the value of crowdsourcing.
Managing to find the talent outside the public sector.
Those people that will use exploit and create value from this data that we provide.
3rd is initiating a dialogue among the various stakeholders.
On the importance of sharing information and its benefits to the public.
Current and potential reuse initiatives by the private sector, civil society and individuals can be publicized to increase awareness of the benefits of opening up data.
Last but not least, our target is to shift the culture of the public sector.
Providing incentives and building new capabilities.
Missing collaborative elements.
Incompleteness of data.
And lack of raw data are not merely technical issues.
Solving these matters implies a fundamental cultural change.
In the public authorities.
The belief that making data public disempowers public officials or make them more vulnerable as a risk unveiling fault.
Kinda times create an environment among civil servants or even policymakers which does not fully support our open data initiative.
Civil servants often feel like a fish in a fishbowl.
If we engage them.
We believe that open data can enable innovation in the public sector and make heroes.
Our goal is to build a network of motivated people within the public sector with the theoretical and technical capabilities required to implement our new policy.
We have already started building this network of people, for example yesterday.
In a sense, we had an event that we organize with a digital nacked project open data support.
Civil servants from all ministries gathered there and discussed and received training in the area of open data.
Aiming to beat theoretical and technical capacity, in particular to favor the uptake of linked open data technologies.
I would also like to mention that the electronic government ministries support the second International Summer School on Open and Collaborative Governance, which will be held this summer in Somers.
From the 30th of June to the 5th of July, covering various thematic areas such as open and Link data Technologies and Big Data Management technologies in policy support.
In order to further promote our policies on open data, our ministry will organize for the first time an open public data hackathon.
Based on the use of open, open public data sets for the development of digital applications.

The hackathon, which is organized in collaboration with a lack the Greek free open source Software society, a nonprofit organization in Greece, and her Acopio University in Athens, aspires to attract open source developers and communities both from the private and public sector, as well as the universities and raise public awareness of the multiple benefits of opening up public sector information.
The open public data hackathon will be held in Athens.
In April.
Participants will be gathered for two weekends at the hard copy or University of Athens.
The first weekend will be mainly for networking and brainstorming.
And the second one for wrapping up their idea, said delivering prototype applications.
The showcase of applications with evaluation and awards will take place in a separate event early in May.
Moreover, open public data hackathon will designate public bodies.
Whose data sets were mostly used as well as those who were more willing to open their data.
With this information or on our public open data heckathorn.
I would like to close this presentation and invite you to participate in it and maybe their neighbors to its success.
And as this is, this presentation is a public sector information.
It will be, of course available on the website of the video.
Outside of the air, so it's available for everyone.
Thank you very much.
